name: USHA ALBUQUERQUE
known_for: Founder director of Careers Smart & Instant Productions
description: Douglas Crockford was born in the Frostbite Falls, Minnesota, but left when he was only six months old because it was just too damn cold. He turned his back on a promising career in television when he discovered computers. He has worked in learning systems, small business systems, office automation, games, interactive music, multimedia, location-based entertainment, social systems, and programming languages. He is the inventor of Tilton, the ugliest programming language that was not specifically designed to be an ugly programming language. He is best known for having discovered that there are good parts in JavaScript. This was an important and unexpected discovery. He also discovered the JSON Data Interchange Format, the world's most loved data format. And he works at Paypal.
topic_description: The Better Parts was a book written by Douglas Crawford.Douglas Crockford is an American computer programmer and entrepreneur who is best known for his ongoing involvement in the development of the JavaScript language, for having popularized the data format JSON (JavaScript Object Notation), and for developing various JavaScript related tools such as JSLint and JSMin.[2] He is currently a senior JavaScript architect at PayPal, and is also a writer and speaker on JavaScript, JSON, and related web technologies such as the Yahoo! User Interface Library (YUI).

name: Sunil Pai
description: Myntra spent the last year or so transitioning over most of their user facing services/pages to node. Sunil was part of this effort, and helped move the company over from a php stack to a service oriented stack around node. He learnt a number of things along the way, and he'd like to share some of these with the rest of the community. Sunil experimented heavily with parallelizing middleware stacks, isomorphic modules, in-house build/deploy systems, SEO-friendly single page applications, and so on. Sunil managed to replace many servers with few, and have a fun ops setup that makes it quite nice to work with.
topic_description: Myntra spent the last year or so transitioning over most of their user facing services/pages to node. I was part of this effort, and helped move the company over from a php stack to a service oriented stack around node. We learnt a number of things along the way, and I'd like to share some of these with the rest of the community. We experimented heavily with parallelizing middleware stacks, isomorphic modules, in-house build/deploy systems, SEO-friendly single page applications, and so on. We managed to replace many servers with few, and have a fun ops setup that makes it quite nice to work with.

name: Suchit Puri
topic: What EmberJS taught us in past year
description: Suchit Puri ,an alumnus from BITS Pilani and currently working as a application developer at Thoughtworks is an agilist and ardent follower of XP best practices like TDD, Pair Programming, Continuous Integration and continuous deployments. He has worked for clients ranging from small startups to big MNC's ; getting involved during project inceptions/client management, juggling many hats; doing analysis, coding, deployments and automation during a project's life-cycle.He has also been doing consulting on Agile Adoption , TDD ,CI.
session: What EmberJS taught us in past year
topic_description:
We have been using EmberJS for past one year now , we started using Ember , Ember-Data when it was just released and Ember-data was still not fit for production.

This talk will talk about the problems we have faced and problem we have solved using this framework.

Whats the EmberJS MV* philosophy , is it really rails for javascript?

How good is Ember-Data for projects , the problems it solves.

How to keep up with ember versions and when to upgrade.

name: Magesh Kuppan
description: Magesh has a rich 17 years of experience in software development, consulting and training. He combines rich technical knowledge and domain expertise in breadth and depth that helps to create extremely rich and powerful end user experience – be it insightful technical discussions during training or powerful software solutions. He had been working on RIA using JavaScript and built custom MVC frameworks in JavaScript before the arrival of the likes of Backbone.js etc.
topic_description:
Functional programming encourages the use of 'Pure functions' that depend only on their inputs and not on the global state. This leads to functions with no 'side effects' which are relatively bug free.

Functions programming gives way for declarative programming paradigm where the users of the api have to deal only with the 'what' aspect of the api rather than the nuances of the 'how'.

The workshops covers the following:

  1. Thinking in terms of 'actions' (functions) rather than 'state' (objects)
  2. Writing pure functions
  3. Avoiding intermediate state by exploiting recursion
  4. Understanding and using 'Higher order functions'
  5. Mastering closures
  6. Implementing some of the Object Oriented Language Design Patterns the functional way.

name: Kapil Manchanda
description: Helps major organizations deploy cutting-edge technology practices to accelerate project and application development, build IT capabilities, and capture substantial cost savings.
topic_description:
1. Understanding when HTML5/JS is Appropriate for Gaming and When it's Not
    1. Pros of HTML5 Gaming
    2. Cons of HTML5 Gaming
    3. Cross Device Alternatives
      1. Unity Engine
      2. Native Porting
      3. WebGL
  2. HTML5 Game Architecture
    1. Loading/Preloading Assets
    2. Asset Hierarchies
    3. Server Interaction
    4. Game Loop
    5. Libraries
  3. Developing the App
    1. Creating the Application Shell
    2. Including Necessary Libraries
    3. Coding the Basic Game Loop
    4. Adding Player Interaction
    5. Adding Animations
    6. Adding Sounds
    7. Adding Scoring
    8. Making the Game Replayable
  4. Testing Across Environments
  5. Release Considerations

name: Amod Malviya
known_for: SVP and Head of Engineering, Flipkart
description: Amod heads the Engineering setup that powers Flipkart.com. Having joined the engineering team during its infancy as a Sr. Engineering Manager, he has grown wearing multiple hats at a time, playing a critical role in helping Flipkart.com reach where it is today. Prior to joining Flipkart.com, Amod has worked at multiple technology startups, mostly into consumer Internet and distributed system spaces. He is an avid technology contributor, a strong open source proponent, and is very passionate about making India a technology powerhouse.
topic_description: 'Short term vs long term' is a conflict often discussed in organisations. Short term approaches give agility and time to market, while long term approaches give robustness and scale. Is there a framework that can be used to arrive at the right balance? In this talk I plan to talk about a set of best practices that have worked for us, that might be of help in determining that balance.

name: Magesh Kuppan
description: Magesh has a rich 17 years of experience in software development, consulting and training. He combines rich technical knowledge and domain expertise in breadth and depth that helps to create extremely rich and powerful end user experience – be it insightful technical discussions during training or powerful software solutions. He had been working on RIA using JavaScript and built custom MVC frameworks in JavaScript before the arrival of the likes of Backbone.js etc.

name: Hemanth HM
description: Hemanth.HM a computer polyglot CLI, web and unix philosophy <3 'r.Works at CISCO as an HTML5 developer. & Blogs about programming .Contributes to FOSS via Github. Core team member of Yeoman.Curators Node Module Of The Week.
topic_description:
Say bye bye to callbackhell not with promises (that's old school) but with ES6 generators! :)

The talk shall be covering:

  1. A detail view of generators.
  2. How they can avoid callbackhell.
  3. What are some of the uber kool node modules that are already using generators (like co, koa and others)
  4. Promises vs Thunks vs Futures.
  5. Some live coding too ;)

name: Joe Pettersson
topic: Build a scalable video chat platform using Node, Kraken, WebRTC and HTML5 video
description: Joe's UI Engineering Lead at McKinsey & Company, specifially at McKinsey Digital Labs. He's passionate about user-interfaces, user-experiences and building kick-ass tools and products. He's been writing JavaScript since the late 1990's, and has a passion for talking about it publically. He's half Swedish and half English, which means that while he loves herring, snow and flat-pack furniture; he also never performs adequatley at international football tournaments.
session: Build a scalable video chat platform using Node, Kraken, WebRTC and HTML5 video

name: Satty Bhens
known_for: Digital Principal at McKinsey Digital Labs
description: Helps major organizations deploy cutting-edge technology practices to accelerate project and application development, build IT capabilities, and capture substantial cost savings.
